questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery is the branch of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thyrocervical trunk

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the subclavian artery's first part. The inferior thyroid artery ascends anterior to the medial border of the scalenus anterior, then turns medially just below the sixth cervical transverse process and descends on longus colli to the thyroid gland's lower border.

 

 

The relationships between the terminal branches and the recurrent laryngeal nerve are highly variable and have significant surgical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External Carotid Artery: The external carotid artery supplies most of the structures in the neck, face, scalp, and the upper part of the skull. This artery has several branches, including the superior thyroid, lingual, facial, maxillary, and superficial temporal arteries, among others. While it does supply areas around the thyroid, especially through its superior thyroid branch, it is not the origin of the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Option B. Internal Carotid Artery: The internal carotid artery has no branches in the neck. Instead, it moves upward to supply the brain and eyes. It's essential for cerebral circulation and plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the brain.

 

Option D. Lingual Artery: The lingual artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. It supplies the muscles and mucosa of the tongue. Given its role and location, it is not involved in supplying the thyroid gland or associated structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyrocervical trunk is a short branch of the subclavian artery, and it supplies numerous structures in the neck. The branches of the thyrocervical trunk are the inferior thyroid artery, the ascending cervical artery, and the transverse cervical artery (which can further divide into superficial and deep branches). The inferior thyroid artery, which arises from the thyrocervical trunk, mainly supplies the thyroid and parathyroid glands.

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger
Loss of sensation at the tip of radial tubercle
Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft

questions.text: Lesion of the structure marked '11' causes: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Loss of sensation of the nail of index finger

 

The structure marked 11 in the diagram is median nerve in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the median nerve causes loss of sensation of the nail of the index finger.

 

Anterior view of the right cubital fossa. The structures marked in the given image are:

 

  1. Branch of the median nerve to the brachialis muscle
  2. Biceps brachii muscle
  3. Brachialis muscle
  4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of fore arm
  5. Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  6. Brachioradialis muscle
  7. Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
  8. Pronator teres muscle
  9. Brachial artery
  10. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm
  11. Median nerve.

 

 

Median nerve cutaneous supply:

 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

 

Cubital fossa boundaries

 

  • An essential point of transition between the arm and the forearm is the cubital fossa. It is a triangle depression produced between two forearm muscles that is anterior to the elbow joint:
  • the brachioradialis muscle originating from the lateral supraepicondylar ridge of the humerus;
  • the pronator teres muscle originating from the medial epicondyle of the humerus

 

Contents of cubital fossa: (From medial to lateral) - "MBBS"

 

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery
  • Biceps brachi tendon
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypothenar muscles wasting: The hypothenar muscles are primarily innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve. Therefore, injury to the median nerve would not directly result in the wasting of these muscles.

 

Option C. Loss of sensation at the tip of the radial tubercle: The radial tubercle refers to the styloid process of the radius, which is not typically innervated by the median nerve. Sensory loss in this area is more likely associated with a different nerve, such as the radial nerve.

 

Option D. Loss of sensation of the 4th interdigital cleft: The median nerve supplies sensory fibers to the radial half of the ring finger, so an injury to the median nerve could result in sensory loss in the 4th interdigital cleft (between the ring finger and the little finger).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median nerve supplies sensory fibers to the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and the radial half of the ring finger. This means that an injury to the median nerve can lead to sensory loss in these areas, including the nail of the index finger.

questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve.

 

Neck of Fibula is the narrowed region just distal to the head of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. This makes the nerve vulnerable at this site, and any injury or compression can affect nerve function.

 

Site 1 – Lateral epicondyle

 

Site 2 – Head of Fibula

 

Site 3 – Neck of Fibula

 

Site 4 – Tibia

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Site 1. Lateral Epicondyle: It is a prominent bony protrusion on the lateral side of the distal end of the humerus, which is the bone of the upper arm. "Tennis elbow" or lateral epicondylitis is a common condition associated with the lateral epicondyle. It's caused by overuse and inflammation of the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle, leading to pain and tenderness at the site.

 

Site 2 - Head of Fibula: It is the proximal, rounded end of the fibula, the smaller of the two leg bones. It's located just below the lateral aspect of the knee joint.

 

This is the location of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which wraps around the neck of the fibula. Injuries or fractures to the head of the fibula may damage this nerve, potentially leading to foot drop.

 

Site 4 - Tibia: It is also known as the shinbone, is the larger, medial, and anterior bone of the leg, located between the knee and the ankle. It is anteromedially placed in the leg and is palpable along its length. The tibia is a common site for fractures, especially the distal part, due to its subcutaneous position. The anterior surface of the tibia, known as the shin, is easily palpable and is often the site of contusions or "shin splints" in athletes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common fibular nerve's course around the neck of the fibula makes this area a hotspot for injuries leading to dorsiflexion failure, underlining the importance of protecting this area from trauma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with acute onset vertigo, dysphagia, ipsilateral facial numbness, and contralateral body sensory loss to pain and temperature. MRI shows infarction in the area colored in red. Which vessel's occlusion is more likely to cause these symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Explanation: 

 

The scenario describes lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome caused by PICA occlusion, characterized by:

  • Vertigo and nystagmus (vestibular nuclei)
  • Dysphagia (nucleus ambiguus)
  • Ipsilateral facial numbness (trigeminal nucleus)
  • Contralateral body sensory loss (spinothalamic tract)
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome
  • Ipsilateral cerebellar signs

 

The PICA is a branch of vertebral artery supplying:

  • Lateral medulla
  • Inferior cerebellum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:

  • Supplies anterior inferior cerebellum
  • Involvement causes internal ear symptoms
  • Different territory than lateral medulla

 

Option C. Superior cerebellar artery:

  • Supplies superior cerebellum
  • No medullary territory
  • Different clinical syndrome

 

Option D. Anterior spinal artery:

  • Supplies anterior 2/3rd of spinal cord
  • Medial medulla (if involved)
  • Causes different syndrome (medial medullary syndrome)

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding PICA territory and Wallenberg syndrome helps in:

  1. Recognizing characteristic clinical features
  2. Differentiating from other brainstem syndromes
  3. Prompt diagnosis and management of stroke
  4. Understanding vascular territories of brainstem

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem of the lateral sulcus

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image points to the region where the parietal lobe and temporal lobe meet. This region is associated with the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to this marked structure, separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central sulcus: Incorrect. The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and is not located in the region marked in the image.

 

Option C. Inferior frontal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus is found on the lateral surface of the frontal lobe and does not correspond to the marked region.

 

Option D. Superior temporal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus runs parallel to the lateral sulcus on the temporal lobe, but it is not deep to the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to the marked structure in the image, which is a critical landmark in neuroanatomy for separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with restricted movement of the elbow joint following trauma. X-ray reveals abnormal bone formation between radius and ulna in the region originally containing what type of joint? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Syndesmosis

 

Explanation: 

 

The scenario describes heterotopic ossification of the middle radioulnar joint, which is normally a syndesmosis. Key features:

  • Normal anatomy: Radius and ulna connected by interosseous membrane
  • Type of joint: Syndesmosis (fibrous joint)
  • Function: Allows pronation and supination
  • Pathology: Post-traumatic ossification can convert syndesmosis to synostosis
  • Result: Restricted forearm rotation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Synostosis:

  • Complete bony fusion
  • This is the pathological end result
  • Not the normal joint type
  • Example: Skull sutures in adults

 

Option C. Synarthrosis:

  • General term for immovable joints
  • Includes sutures, gomphosis
  • Not specific to radioulnar joint
  • No movement allowed

 

Option D. Synchondrosis:

  • Hyaline cartilage joint
  • Temporary during growth
  • Example: Growth plates
  • Not found in radioulnar area

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that:

  1. Middle radioulnar joint is normally a syndesmosis
  2. Post-traumatic ossification can convert it to synostosis
  3. This conversion restricts normal pronation-supination movements
  4. Early recognition prevents permanent functional limitation

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

questions.text: During endoscopy, the endoscope has reached 25 cm from the incisor teeth. The endoscope has reached till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, the distance from the incisor teeth to various anatomical landmarks in the esophagus is measured in centimeters. The esophagus is a muscular tube that passes through the thorax to the stomach. The significant landmarks that the endoscope passes as it moves down include the pharyngo-esophageal junction, the arch of the aorta, the left bronchus, and finally the diaphragm.

 

At 25 cm from the incisor teeth, the endoscope reaches the level of the arch of aorta. This is anatomically located around the T4 vertebra level. The arch of aorta causes a slight indentation in the esophagus, which is why it's a key point of reference during endoscopy.

 

 

 

Cricopharyngeal junction - C6 – 6” (15 cm)

 

Arch of aorta - T4 – 9” (22.5 cm)

 

Left bronchus - T6 – 11” (27.5 cm)

 

Diaphragm - T10 – 15” (37.5 cm)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left bronchus: The left bronchus is located slightly below the arch of aorta, typically around 27.5 cm from the incisor teeth, corresponding to the T6 vertebra level. Therefore, at 25 cm, the endoscope has not yet reached the left bronchus.

 

Option B. Main bronchus: The term "main bronchus" is often a general term that could refer to either the left or right bronchus. However, anatomically, both bronchi are located below the level of the arch of aorta, making this option incorrect for the 25 cm mark.

 

Option C. Right bronchus: The right bronchus, similar to the left, is located at a point beyond 25 cm from the incisor teeth, typically after the endoscope has passed the level of the arch of aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At 25 cm from the incisor teeth during an endoscopy, the endoscope has reached the level of the arch of aorta. This is a crucial anatomical landmark and is typically located at the T4 vertebra level

questions.text: Which of the following structures given below is related to the structure highlighted green in image? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pudendal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in green is the ischial spine and the pudendal nerve is related to it.

 

The ischial spine is a bony projection from the posterior part of the ischium in the pelvis

 

The pudendal nerve originates from the sacral plexus S2-S4. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around the ischial spine. The ischial spine is used as a landmark for pudendal nerve block.

 

 

  1. Sensory function: The pudendal nerve provides sensation to the external genitalia, perineum, and anus.
  2. Motor function: The pudendal nerve also supplies motor function to the pelvic floor muscles, including the external anal sphincter, bulbospongiosus muscle, and ischiocavernosus muscle.
  3. Sexual function: The pudendal nerve plays a crucial role in sexual function by supplying motor and sensory innervation to the genital organs.
  4. Urinary and fecal continence: The pudendal nerve is involved in maintaining urinary and fecal continence by controlling the external anal sphincter muscle. Damage to the pudendal nerve can lead to incontinence, which is the loss of control over urinary or fecal elimination.Top of Form

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and originates from the sacral plexus (L4-S3). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, below the piriformis muscle. While it is near the ischial spine, it descends posteriorly down the thigh, dividing into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves. It provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior thigh and most of the leg and foot. Its relation to the ischial spine is less clinically significant than the pudendal nerve's.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen and provides sensory and motor innervation to the medial thigh. In terms of its relationship to the ischial spine, it is anatomically distinct, as it courses more anteriorly in the pelvis, and it doesn't have significant clinical associations with the ischial spine.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve also originates from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It descends through the psoas muscle and enters the thigh beneath the inguinal ligament. It provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. The femoral nerve's course is anterior in the pelvis, and it doesn't have a direct relationship or significant clinical association with the ischial spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus (S2-S4 nerve roots). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, just inferior to the piriformis muscle. It then courses around the ischial spine and re-enters the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen. The pudendal nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineal region and external genitalia. Due to its proximity to the ischial spine, the pudendal nerve can be blocked for pain relief during childbirth and certain surgical procedures in the perineal region.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: In the cadaveric specimen shown, which nerve is marked by the black arrow? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial pectoral nerve

 

The nerve marked in the image is the medial pectoral nerve. This nerve specifically pierces the pectoralis minor muscle. In the pectoral region, the large muscle visible is the pectoralis major, and when this muscle is cut, the pectoralis minor is seen underneath. The medial pectoral nerve is responsible for innervating both the pectoralis minor and major muscles. The distinguishing feature of this nerve is its penetration through the pectoralis minor muscle, making it identifiable in anatomical images.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle and does not have any direct association with the pectoralis muscles or the clavipectoral fascia, making it an incorrect choice in this context.

 

Option B. Lateral pectoral nerve: The lateral pectoral nerve primarily supplies the pectoralis major muscle and pierces the clavipectoral fascia between the clavicle and the pectoralis minor, not the muscle itself. Thus, it is not the nerve marked in the image.

 

Option D. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, located along the lateral thoracic wall, and does not pierce the pectoralis minor, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial pectoral nerve is the nerve that pierces the pectoralis minor muscle and also provides innervation to the pectoralis major.

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into brachiocephalic vein? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Left superior intercostal vein

 

Explanation:

 

The left superior intercostal vein  directly drain into the brachiocephalic vein. This vein collects venous blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiazygous Vein: The hemiazygous vein is a tributary of the azygos vein, not the brachiocephalic vein. It drains blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall.

 

Option B. Superior Thyroid Vein : It drain into the internal jugular vein, not directly into the brachiocephalic vein. They carry blood from the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Right Superior Intercostal Vein: It is formed by union of 2nd, 3rd, and 4th right posterior intercostal veins). It drains into the azygous vein. It serves as a major channel for venous blood from the right side of the posterior thoracic wall to return to the superior vena cava and ultimately to the right atrium of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tributaries of the brachiocephalic vein:

 

  • Left and right internal thoracic veins
  • Left and right inferior thyroid veins
  • Left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.
  • The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein.

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2nd Palmar interossei

 

The dorsal digital extension of the middle finger is the structure indicated in the picture. The middle finger's dorsal digital extension is not aided by the palmar interossei because they do not attach to the middle finger.

 

The palmar interossei muscles are also located between the metacarpal bones but are found on the palmar side of the hand. Their primary function is to adduct the fingers. Unlike the dorsal interossei, the palmar interossei insert only into the bases of the proximal phalanges and do not extend to the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd palmar interosseous does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Extensor hoods, also known as "dorsal digital expansions," are formed when the tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus muscles cross over the dorsal aspect of the digits and extend over the proximal phalanges. These hoods are connected by the tendons of the extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.

 

 

 

The dorsal digital expansion, also known as the extensor hood or extensor expansion, is a complex aponeurotic structure found on the dorsal aspect of each finger. It serves as the insertion point for certain tendons and allows the extensor tendons to provide extension at all three finger joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd Dorsal interossei: The dorsal interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones and are primarily responsible for the abduction of the fingers. There are four dorsal interossei in the hand. The tendons of the dorsal interossei insert into the bases of the proximal phalanges and into the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd dorsal interosseous does contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option B. Lumbricals: The lumbricals are four small muscles in the hand that arise from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons. Their primary function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. The tendons of the lumbricals insert into the dorsal digital expansion on the radial sides of the fingers. Hence, lumbricals do contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: The extensor digitorum muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. It extends down the forearm and sends tendons to the fingers. These tendons attach to the dorsal digital expansion and primarily facilitate the extension of the fingers. Thus, the extensor digitorum directly contributes to the formation of the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal digital expansion plays a key role in extending the finger joints and is formed by the integration of tendons from several muscles, excluding the 2nd Palmar interossei, which primarily functions in adduction and does not extend to the dorsal side of the fingers.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the marked foramen marked 2 in the image below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oculomotor nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is the superior orbital fissure and the oculomotor nerve passes through this fissure.

 

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring. The oculomotor nerve passes through its intermediate compartment.

 

 

The oculomotor nerve primarily controls the movements of several eye muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris (lifts the upper eyelid), and the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, which control eye movements. It also controls the constriction of the pupil (miosis) and accommodation of the lens for near vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Olfactory Nerve (CN I):

 

  • The olfactory nerve originates from the olfactory bulbs, which are extensions of the brain, located on the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone within the anterior cranial fossa.

 

  • The olfactory nerve is responsible for the sense of smell. It carries sensory information related to odors from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

Option C. Optic Nerve (CN II):

 

  • The optic nerve emerges from the optic canal, which is located in the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone within the middle cranial fossa.

 

  • The optic nerve is crucial for vision. It transmits visual information from the retina to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual stimuli.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • The facial nerve emerge from a stylomastoid foramen from the base of the skull.

 

  • It controls the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the production of saliva and tears. It also carries sensory information related to taste.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Examine the histological section provided. Which type of cartilage is shown in the image?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. White fibrocartilage

 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

 

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

 

  • Chondrocytes- Round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- Type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

 

Note - White fibrocartilage is dense with collagen fibers (primarily type I collagen), which gives a great tensile strength. It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and places where tendons insert into bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: It's a type of hyaline cartilage not involved in joint articulations. The matrix contains a moderate amount of collagen fibers, predominantly type II collagen, making it tough but somewhat flexible. It is found in the respiratory tract (including the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cartilages), growth plates of bones, and the anterior aspect of ribs (costal cartilages).

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: It is similar in composition to non-articular hyaline cartilage, but specifically lines the surfaces of bones in synovial joints. It covers the ends of bones in synovial joints such as the knee, shoulder, and hip.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): It contains elastic fibers and collagen fibers, mainly type II collagen. The elastic fibers give it more flexibility than hyaline cartilage. It is found in the ear pinna (auricle), epiglottis, and auditory (Eustachian) tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Longitudinal growth of a long bone is most likely affected by a fracture involving which of the following regions? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate


The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis (end) and the metaphysis of a long bone. This plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones during childhood and adolescence. Active cell division occurs here, which contributes to the lengthening of the bone. Any damage or fracture at the epiphyseal plate can disrupt this growth process, leading to potential growth abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone but is not directly responsible for bone growth. Fractures here do not significantly impact the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Option B. Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the flared part of the bone between the diaphysis and the epiphyseal plate. Although it plays a role in supporting growth, fractures here do not directly disrupt the longitudinal growth as much as a fracture at the epiphyseal plate would.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the shaft or central part of the long bone. Fractures in the diaphysis typically affect the strength and integrity of the bone but do not interfere with growth lengthwise.

 

Educational Objective:


The epiphyseal plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones, and fractures here can significantly impact this process.

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

choices.text: Esophageal branch of left gastric artery

questions.text: All of the following structures pass through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm, except: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Thoracic duct

 

Explanation:

 

The thoracic duct does not pass through the esophageal hiatus; it passes through the aortic opening. The esophageal hiatus, located at the T10 vertebral level, allows the passage of the esophagus and other structures, such as the esophageal branch of the left gastric artery, and the vagus nerves. The aortic opening, at the T12 vertebral level, is where the aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein pass through.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal branch of left gastric artery: This artery passes through the esophageal hiatus along with the esophagus.

 

Option B. Left vagus nerve: The left vagus nerve passes through the esophageal hiatus, providing parasympathetic innervation to the esophagus and other abdominal organs.

 

Option C. Right vagus nerve: The right vagus nerve also passes through the esophageal hiatus, accompanying the esophagus into the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thoracic duct passes through the aortic opening, not the esophageal hiatus.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

 

The supracardinal vein gives rise to the structure indicated in the provided figure, which is the azygos vein.

 

The vein network known as the azygos system serves as a conduit between the superior and inferior venae caves. It resides in the posterior mediastinum and higher portion of the posterior abdominal wall. Moreover, it links the vertebral venous, caval, and portal systems. It drains the top part of the lumbar spine and the thoracic wall.

 

Development: The azygos venous system arises from the supra cardinal veins embryologically. The right supra cardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while the left supra cardinal vein becomes the hemiazygos vein.

 

  • The 4th to 11th right intercostal veins empties into the right supracardinal vein, which together with a portion of the posterior cardinal vein forms the azygos vein.
  • On the left, the 4th to 7th intercostal veins enters into the left supracardinal vein, and the left supracardinal vein, then known as the hemiazygos vein, which also empties into the azygos vein.
  • Cardinal veins form the main venous drainage system of the embryo. It consists of,
  • Anterior cardinal veins, which drain the cephalic part of the embryo, and
  • Posterior cardinal veins, which drain the rest of the embryo.

 

During the fifth to the seventh weeks, a number of additional veins are formed. It includes,

 

  • Subcardinal veins, which mainly drain the kidneys;
  • Sacrocardinal veins, which drain the lower extremities;
  • Supracardinal veins, which drain the body wall by way of the intercostal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common cardinal vein: common cardinal veins drain the embryonic body into the sinus venosus. These are early, primitive venous systems that mainly regress but give rise to parts of the systemic venous system. Specifically, the common cardinal vein will give rise to the sinus venarum of the right atrium and the oblique vein of the left atrium.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal vein: The anterior cardinal veins develop later and drain the cranial part of the embryo. With further development, the bilateral anterior cardinal veins will form the internal jugular vein and the brachiocephalic vein after some remodeling and anastomosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Option D. Subcardinal vein: The subcardinal veins primarily play a role in the development of the renal and gonadal venous systems. They give rise to the renal segment of the inferior vena cava and the gonadal veins. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

The marked structure in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

The flask-shaped cells known as Purkinje cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are positioned in a single layer between the molecular and granular cell layers, evenly spaced apart. Each cell's axon travels downhill, crosses the granular cell layer, and ends on the deep cerebellar nuclei, while each cell's dendrite travels upward to enter the molecular layer. They utilize GABA as their neurotransmitter and are inhibitory.

 

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers.

 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vestibular nuclei: The vestibular nuclei are located in the brainstem and are primarily involved in processing information related to balance and spatial orientation from the inner ear. While Purkinje cells can send inhibitory outputs that influence the activity of the vestibular nuclei indirectly, it is not their direct and primary target.

 

Option C. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. It sends excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, specifically to the Purkinje cells, via climbing fibers. These fibers have a strong excitatory influence on Purkinje cells, but Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the inferior olivary nucleus.

 

Option D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are associated with a variety of functions, including the regulation of voluntary motor movements, procedural learning, and cognition. While there are complex interactions between the cerebellum and basal ganglia, particularly at the level of the thalamus, Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: The white line corresponds to which vertebral level? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The white line shown in the image corresponds to the Transpyloric plane, which passes through the Lower border of L1 vertebral level. 

  1. Transpyloric plane (white line): Passes through the lower border of L1 vertebra
  2. Subcostal plane: Passes through the upper border of L3 vertebra
  3. Transtubercular plane (green line): Passes through the upper border of L5 vertebra

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L3: This corresponds to the subcoastal line, Passes through the upper border of L3 vertebra

 

Option C. L5: This corresponds to the transtubercular plane, which is shown by the green line in the lower abdomen.

 

Option D. T12: This vertebral level is located in the thoracic region and would be above all the planes shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Transpyloric plane passes through the L1 vertebral level and corresponds to the upperborder of vertebra, serving as an important anatomical landmark for identifying the position of various abdominal structures.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of brachial plexus do not give branches? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Divisions

 

Explanation:

 

The divisions in the brachial plexus do not give any branches.

 

However, the roots, trunks, and cords of the brachial plexus give out direct branches.

 

The brachial plexus is a complex network of nerves that originates from the ventral rami of the fifth cervical to the first thoracic spinal nerves (C5-T1). The brachial plexus is typically organized into five stages: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and terminal branches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roots: The roots of the brachial plexus are the five ventral rami (C5-T1) that serve as the origin of the brachial plexus. These roots give off several branches:

 

  • C5 root can contribute to the dorsal scapular nerve.
  • C5 and C6 roots together give rise to the upper trunk, but before they merge, they can give off the nerve to the subclavius muscle (from C5 and C6).
  • C8 and T1 roots can contribute to the long thoracic nerve along with C7 root.

 

Option B. Cords: The cords are named based on their position relative to the axillary artery: lateral, medial, and posterior cords.

 

  • The lateral cord gives branches like the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The medial cord gives branches like the medial pectoral, medial cutaneous nerve of arm, and medial cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • The posterior cord provides branches like the upper subscapular, thoracodorsal, and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option C. Trunks: There are three trunks in the brachial plexus: upper, middle, and lower.

 

  • The upper trunk is formed by the union of C5 and C6 roots and gives off the suprascapular nerve and the nerve to the omohyoid muscle.
  • The middle and lower trunks usually do not give any significant branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each trunk divides into two divisions: an anterior division and a posterior division. The divisions do not provide any branches.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

 

  • The clinical vignette presented in a patient with difficulty flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, as well as loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • One of the most common causes of humerus fractures is a fall from a great height on an outstretched hand.

 

Musculocutaneous Nerve:

 

It is a branch of the brachial plexus, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in the arm.

 

Muscles Innervated: Supplies the brachialis, biceps brachii, and coracobrachialis muscles.

 

Sensory Distribution: Sends sensory fibers as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, providing sensation to the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm.

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm due to affected biceps. Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and enters the forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Primarily supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and thenar muscles in the hand.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the lateral (radial) three and a half fingers and the corresponding palm area.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of flexion of the wrist, loss of flexion of lateral fingers, and loss of thumb opposition. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve: It also originates from the brachial plexus and travels posteriorly in the arm.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the triceps brachii and the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the back of the arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand on the radial side.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Wrist drop" due to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and passes posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus (the "funny bone").

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies many of the small muscles of the hand and some flexors in the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the medial (ulnar) one and a half fingers and the corresponding area of the palm and dorsum.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Claw hand" deformity due to loss of function in the ulnar half of the hand. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness in performing daily activities. On examination, the clinician asked her to make an 'O' using her thumb and index finger, which she was unable to do. Which of the following muscles is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to form an 'O' using the thumb and index finger suggests a problem with muscles that control flexion of these digits, specifically the flexor pollicis longus, which is responsible for flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx. This muscle is innervated by the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. The condition described in the question is consistent with anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, which impairs the flexion of the distal phalanges of the thumb and index finger, making it difficult to perform tasks requiring precise pinch or grip, such as buttoning a shirt.

 

In Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus are affected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmar interossei: These muscles are primarily involved in the adduction of the fingers (PAD - Palmar Adducts), and they do not play a role in flexing the thumb or index finger. Therefore, they are not related to the inability to form an 'O'.

 

Option B. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in the opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the other fingers. It is not directly responsible for flexion of the thumb or index finger and is innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve. Its dysfunction would affect opposition rather than the ability to form an 'O'.

 

Note an update - Opponens pollicis, a hybrid muscle, as innervated by the lateral terminal branch of the median nerve, and commonly by a branch of the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is responsible for the abduction of the thumb, moving it away from the palm. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb at the distal phalanx, which is necessary to form an 'O'. Thus, its involvement does not explain the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome affects the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus muscles, leading to difficulty in forming an 'O' with the thumb and index finger due to impaired flexion.

questions.text: Which marked structure is primarily involved in medial rotation, adduction, and flexion of the hip joint, along with assisting knee flexion? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked '3' in the image corresponds to the adductor longus, a muscle of the medial compartment of the thigh.

 

Adductor Longus:

 

  • Action: The adductor longus performs adduction, flexion, and medial rotation of the hip joint. It plays a key role in stabilizing the pelvis during activities such as walking or running. Although it does not primarily act on the knee, its role in stabilizing the thigh indirectly contributes to lower limb movements.
  • Origin and Insertion: The adductor longus originates from the body of the pubis and inserts on the middle third of the linea aspera of the femur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 - Rectus Femoris (Incorrect): The rectus femoris is a part of the quadriceps femoris group. It flexes the hip and extends the knee, but it does not contribute to adduction or medial rotation at the hip.

 

Option B. 2 - Vastus Lateralis (Incorrect): The vastus lateralis, another muscle of the quadriceps group, is involved only in knee extension. It does not act on the hip joint.

 

Option D. 4 - Sartorius (Incorrect): The sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip and flexion at the knee. It does not contribute to medial rotation or adduction at the hip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adductor longus is a key muscle of the medial compartment of the thigh and is primarily responsible for adduction, flexion, and medial rotation of the hip joint. It is crucial for lower limb stability during locomotion and is innervated by the obturator nerve (L2-L4).

questions.text: Identify the structure marked: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal capsule

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure situated between the thalamus and the lentiform nucleus. It contains important pathways that carry motor and sensory information to and from the cerebral cortex. In the provided image, the marked structure lies outside the thalamus and appears as a bundle of white matter, which is characteristic of the internal capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: The thalamus is located medial to the internal capsule and is not the structure marked in the image. The thalamus serves as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex.

 

Option B. Lentiform nucleus: The lentiform nucleus, which includes the putamen and globus pallidus, is situated lateral to the internal capsule. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Option C. Caudate: The caudate nucleus is located superior to the thalamus and medial to the internal capsule. It is also not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal capsule is a key white matter structure that lies between the thalamus and the lentiform nucleus, transmitting important motor and sensory pathways to the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: Given is a model of embryological development of the heart. Which structure develops from the area marked with red arrow?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Infundibulum

 

Explanation:

 

The marked object is the conus cordis (middle part of bulbus cordis). From this structure, the heart's infundibulum emerges.

 

The heart is represented in the model at the stage of embryology where both heart tubes have merged and are undergoing dextro-looping, or bending. During day 23 of intrauterine life, this occurs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atria: The atria of the heart primarily develop from the primitive atrial chamber or sinus venosus, not from the conus cordis. The sinus venosus will contribute to the formation of the smooth parts of the right and left atria. The atrial appendages or auricles, however, develop from the primitive atrium.

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: The left ventricle arises mainly from the primitive ventricle of the embryonic heart tube. As the heart develops, the primitive ventricle gives rise to the muscular parts of both the left and right ventricles, but primarily the left.

 

Option D. Interventricular septum:The interventricular septum separates the right and left ventricles. It has a muscular part and a membranous part. The muscular part primarily develops from the growth of the myocardium of the primitive ventricle. The conus cordis and the truncus arteriosus contribute to the formation of the membranous part of the interventricular septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The infundibulum, also referred as the conus arteriosus or the outflow tract, develops from the conus cordis. It represents the smooth-walled, anterior portion of the right ventricle and leads to the pulmonary trunk in the mature heart.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most conspicuous sign of breast cancer?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Peaud'orange

 

Explanation:

 

The most conspicuous sign of breast cancer is Peau d' orange appearance.

 

Peaud'orange (orange peel like texture), is the edematous swollen and pitted breast skin due to obstruction of the subcutaneous lymphatics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nipple retraction: Nipple retraction, or inversion, is another potential sign of breast cancer. In some cases, a cancerous lump or tumor can pull on the tissues surrounding the nipple, causing it to retract or appear inverted. However, nipple retraction can also be a benign condition and may not always indicate breast cancer.

 

Option C. Puckering: Puckering of the breast skin can occur when there is an underlying mass or tumor. This may cause changes in the normal contours of the breast, leading to visible puckering or dimpling. Like nipple retraction, puckering can result from both cancerous and non-cancerous breast conditions.

 

Option D. Both nipple retraction and puckering: Some individuals may present with both nipple retraction and puckering as signs of breast cancer. These signs may indicate the presence of a tumor or mass within the breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange term refers to the "orange peel" appearance of the skin on the breast. It is characterized by dimpling or thickening of the skin that resembles the texture of an orange peel.

 

Peau d'orange can be a sign of advanced breast cancer. It occurs when cancer cells block the lymphatic channels in the breast, causing the skin to pucker and become swollen. While it is a significant sign of breast cancer, it typically indicates a more advanced stage of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The middle meningeal artery (MMA) is a branch of the maxillary artery (a terminal branch of the external carotid artery). The MMA enters the middle cranial fossa by passing through the foramen spinosum. After entering the skull, it courses laterally to the pterion.

 

Given the proximity of the MMA to the pterion, trauma to this region can lead to an extradural (epidural) hematoma if the MMA is torn. This is because the MMA runs just deep to the pterion, between the skull and the dura mater.

 

This makes the MMA the artery most closely related to the pterion, and a fracture at the pterion can lead to rupture of this artery.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal carotid artery:

 

  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) is a major artery that supplies blood to the brain. It arises from the common carotid artery and enters the cranial cavity through the carotid canal.
  • While the ICA does travel inside the skull and provides blood to the brain, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion. It is more medial in its course.

 

Option C. Anterior cerebral artery:

 

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. It supplies the medial and superior parts of the brain.
  • Though it's an essential artery for cerebral circulation, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion, as its course and distribution are more medial.

 

Option D. Deep temporal artery:

 

  • The deep temporal arteries are branches of the maxillary artery that ascend between the temporalis muscle and the side of the skull.
  • They supply the temporalis muscle, and while they are in the vicinity of the pterion, they are not as closely related as the middle meningeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

 

Given that it rests across the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere, it is a significant structure. Since the bone in this region is fragile, any injury could cause the middle meningeal artery to burst, resulting in an extradural hematoma.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Broca's area

 

Broca's area (areas 44, 45) in this patient is damaged. This is located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, usually in the dominant hemisphere (the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals).

 

Function: Broca’s area is critical for speech production and grammar processing. Damage to Broca's area results in expressive or non-fluent aphasia. Patients typically understand spoken language and know what they want to say but struggle to form words or construct sentences. Their speech might be slow, with a struggle to find the right words, and they might omit small connecting words like "is" or "the."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's Area:

 

  • Location: This area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in about 95% of right-handed individuals and 70% of left-handed individuals.
  • Function: Wernicke's area is involved in language comprehension. Damage to this area results in receptive aphasia. Patients can produce speech, but it often lacks meaning, and they have difficulty understanding spoken or written language. Their speech might be fluent, but it's usually nonsensical or includes made-up words.

 

Option C. Heschl's Gyrus:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary auditory cortex within the Sylvian fissure in the temporal lobe.
  • Function: Heschl's gyrus is responsible for primary auditory processing, meaning it processes incoming auditory information. Damage to this area might impair the ability to perceive sounds.

 

Option D. Striate Area:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
  • Function: The striate area (or V1) is the primary processing center for visual information. Damage to this area can lead to blindness or partial visual field deficits depending on the extent and location of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.
The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen.
The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance.
The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

 

 

  • The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape: This statement is false. The right adrenal gland is actually pyramidal in shape. The left adrenal gland is semi-lunar (crescent-shaped) in shape. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen: This statement is true. The left adrenal gland is anatomically positioned near the tail of the pancreas and the spleen.

 

Option C. The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance: This statement is true. The adrenal glands have a yellowish appearance on gross examination due to their rich lipid content.

 

Option D. The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location: This statement is true. The adrenal glands, like the kidneys, are retroperitoneal, meaning they are located behind the peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape, while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET May 2021)

 

1. Superior gluteal artery

2. Inferior gluteal artery

3. Superior vesical artery

4. Middle rectal artery

5. Inferior vesical artery

6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

 

The internal iliac artery serves as a major artery supplying the pelvic organs, walls, and gluteal region. It divides into anterior and posterior divisions, each giving rise to specific branches that supply different pelvic structures. The branches of the anterior division typically supply the pelvic viscera and some pelvic walls.

 

 

Branches from the anterior division:

 

2. Inferior gluteal artery : Supplies the buttock and lower limb.

 

3. Superior vesical artery : Supplies the bladder and can contribute to the upper ureter and seminal vesicles.

 

4. Middle rectal artery : Supplies the rectum.

 

5. Inferior vesical artery : Supplies the bladder, prostate, and seminal vesicles in males; replaced by the vaginal artery in females.

 

6. Vaginal artery : Supplies the vagina and base of the bladder in females; it is often considered the female equivalent of the inferior vesical artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

questions.text: Neurotransmitter secreted by the area marked A in the given image is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dopamine

 

Explanation:

 

The substantia nigra is the region highlighted in the illustration (meaning- dark substance). Dopamine is the neurotransmitter released by this region.

 

A component of the nigrostriatal pathway is the substantia nigra. Parkinson's disease may be caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine (ACh):

 

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays key roles in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS).
  • In the PNS, ACh is the neurotransmitter released from the axon terminals of motor neurons, making muscles contract. It's also the neurotransmitter in all autonomic ganglia.
  • In the CNS, ACh is involved in a variety of functions, such as attention, arousal, and memory. Loss of cholinergic neurons in the brain, especially in the basal nucleus of Meynert, has been linked with Alzheimer's disease.
  • However, ACh is not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Glutamine:

 

  • It's worth noting that there's a potential mix-up in the options: Glutamine is an amino acid, while "glutamate" is the neurotransmitter.
  • Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS and plays crucial roles in synaptic plasticity, which is the cellular basis for learning and memory.
  • While glutamate is widespread in the brain, it's not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Noradrenaline :

 

  • Noradrenaline is both a hormone and a neurotransmitter. It plays roles in attention, focus, and the fight-or-flight response by preparing the body to react to threats.
  • In the CNS, noradrenergic neurons primarily arise from the locus coeruleus in the pons and project to various regions of the brain, influencing attention, arousal, and mood.
  • While noradrenaline plays a role in various brain functions, it's not the neurotransmitter secreted by the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine:

 

Dopamine is one of the major neurotransmitters in the brain and is involved in several key functions, including mood regulation, reward-seeking behavior, and motor control.

 

The substantia nigra, specifically its pars compacta region, contains dopaminergic neurons that project to the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). This pathway is known as the nigrostriatal pathway and is critical for regulating voluntary movement.

 

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is the primary pathological feature of Parkinson's disease, leading to motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High median nerve

 

The symptoms described in the question indicate involvement of the median nerve, particularly the high median nerve.
