The high median nerve innervates the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, controls thumb movement, and supplies the thenar muscles responsible for thumb functions. Injury to this nerve can lead to sensory loss and motor deficits, such as difficulty moving the thumb and thenar atrophy, as mentioned in the question. The presence of sensory loss, along with thenar atrophy, strongly indicates a high median nerve injury, rather than its branches like the anterior interosseous nerve, which does not affect sensory perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies the medial side of the hand, including the little finger and half of the ring finger. It does not innervate the lateral 3 ½ fingers or the thenar muscles. Therefore, an injury to the ulnar nerve would not present with the described sensory and motor deficits.

 

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and provides sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand. It does not supply the thenar muscles or the palmar side of the fingers described in the question. Hence, it cannot be the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve: This nerve is a deep branch of the median nerve, which primarily supplies deep muscles in the forearm like the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of the flexor digitorum profundus. It does not carry sensory fibers, so it would not cause sensory loss or thenar atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved in taste sensation?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hypoglossal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The hypoglossal nerve is purely motor cranial nerve and is not involved in taste sensation.

 

All intrinsic and the majority of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue are innervated by General Somatic Efferent fibres, which are motor fibres that supply skeletal muscles. It emerges as many rootlets from the medulla's front surface, travels laterally across the posterior cerebral fossa, and then leaves through the hypoglossal canal. All intrinsic tongue muscles, including the hyoglossus, styloglossus, and genioglossus muscles, are innervated by this nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve (CN V): The trigeminal nerve a mixed cranial nerve primarily responsible for sensations in the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. While it is not directly involved in olfaction (smell), it can indirectly influence the perception of smell. Irritants or substances that produce strong odors can activate the trigeminal nerve's pain and temperature receptors in the nasal passages, leading to sensations like "spiciness" or irritation when inhaling certain substances.

 

Option B. Vagus nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is not directly involved in olfaction. It primarily serves functions related to the autonomic nervous system, including controlling various organs and muscles in the thoracic and abdominal regions. It does not have a direct role in the sense of smell but Vagal nerve stimulation modifies the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve is also a mixed cranial nerve and not directly involved in olfaction. It has various functions, including the transmission of sensory information from the back of the throat and parts of the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is primarily responsible for the motor control of the muscles of the tongue. It does not have any direct involvement in olfaction or the sense of smell.

questions.text: A person fell in the dark while climbing stairs and sustained an injury to the posterior triangle of the neck from an iron nail. Afterwards, he experienced difficulty in raising his shoulder and was unable to shrug. Which structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Accessory nerve

 

The accessory nerve, also known as the 11th cranial nerve, innervates the trapezius muscle. The trapezius muscle is responsible for movements such as shrugging the shoulders. An injury to the posterior triangle of the neck could damage the accessory nerve, leading to weakness in the trapezius muscle. This would manifest as difficulty in raising the shoulder and an inability to shrug, as described in the scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in the movement of the scapula, not shrugging of the shoulder. Damage to this nerve typically leads to a condition known as "winged scapula," not an inability to shrug.

 

Option B. Deltoid muscle: The deltoid muscle is responsible for the abduction of the arm, particularly the movement of the arm away from the body. While it plays a role in shoulder movement, it is not involved in shrugging the shoulder.

 

Option D. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: This muscle is involved in turning the chin to the opposite side and flexing the neck. It is not responsible for shoulder elevation or shrugging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accessory nerve is crucial for the function of the trapezius muscle, which enables the shrugging of the shoulder. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to perform this action.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontanelle tap is a critical emergency procedure used in infants for CSF sampling or pressure relief from the ventricles, exploiting the unossified sections of the skull for direct access to the CSF. This procedure is unique to neonates and young infants where the fontanelle is present and typically involves piercing the scalp, dura, and arachnoid layers.

questions.text: Identify the structure being palpated in the image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial artery

 

The image shows a hand palpating the area just behind the medial malleolus (the bony prominence on the inner side of the ankle). The structure located in this region is the posterior tibial artery. This artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to the lower leg and foot. It can be palpated in this location to assess blood flow to the foot, and its pulse is an important clinical sign in assessing peripheral circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plantar artery: The plantar arteries are found on the sole of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus. Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery is located on the front of the lower leg, not behind the medial malleolus. It is not the structure being palpated in this image.

 

Option D. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is located on the top of the foot, near the ankle, but it is not found behind the medial malleolus. Therefore, this is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery can be palpated just behind the medial malleolus, and this is a key location for assessing the arterial blood supply to the foot.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

 

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lienorenal ligament: This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney and contains the tail of the pancreas and vessels that supply the spleen. It helps to hold the spleen in its anatomical position, preventing it from moving medially.

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. It contains the short gastric vessels and contributes to the attachment of the spleen to the stomach. It prevents the spleen from moving too far posteriorly.

 

Option D. Lienophrenic ligament: The term "lienophrenic ligament" isn't a standard anatomical term. The spleen does have ligamentous connections with the diaphragm, but these are typically referred to as part of the lienorenal and gastrosplenic ligaments. Therefore, this option might be a misnomer or less commonly used terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrenicocolic ligament extends from the left colic (splenic) flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It's positioned to the left side of the abdomen and is an important anatomical landmark. It acts as a supportive structure, supporting the left colic flexure and acting as a barrier. Importantly, it prevents the downward and medial displacement of the spleen, especially when the spleen enlarges, as in cases of splenomegaly.

 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

questions.text: What is the postnatal remnant of the distal umbilical artery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Medial umbilical ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The distal part of the umbilical artery transforms into the medial umbilical ligament postnatally. This occurs as part of the normal circulatory changes following birth when the placental circulation is no longer needed. The proximal portions of the umbilical arteries remain patent and form the superior vesical arteries, while the distal portions become fibrous cords that appear as medial umbilical folds on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum teres: This is incorrect. The ligamentum teres is the postnatal remnant of the umbilical vein, not the umbilical artery. It extends from the umbilicus to the porta hepatis and represents the obliterated umbilical vein.

 

Option B. Superior vesical artery: This is incorrect. The superior vesical artery is derived from the proximal portion of the umbilical artery that remains patent after birth, not the distal portion which becomes ligamentous.

 

Option D. Ligamentum arteriosum: This is incorrect. The ligamentum arteriosum is the postnatal remnant of the ductus arteriosus (which connects the pulmonary trunk to the aorta in fetal life), not the umbilical artery.

 

Education Objective:

 

The distal parts of paired umbilical arteries, after cessation of placental circulation at birth, become fibrous cords known as medial umbilical ligaments, while their proximal portions remain patent as the superior vesical arteries.

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertensive patient presents with sudden onset vertigo, dysphagia, hoarseness of voice, and left-sided ataxia. On examination, there is loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and left side of the face, along with left-sided Horner's syndrome. The lesion is most likely located at? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lateral medulla

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario describes Wallenberg's syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome), which occurs due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery or vertebral artery affecting the lateral medulla.

 

Key clinical features suggesting lateral medullary syndrome:

 

Lesions in this region (often due to Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome) would result in:

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face due to the involvement of the descending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to the involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus.
  • Vertigo, nausea, nystagmus due to vestibular nuclei involvement.
  • Ataxia and dysmetria because of the involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Medulla: Would present with:

  • Ipsilateral tongue deviation (CN XII)
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Contralateral loss of position and vibration sense

 

Option B. Lateral Pons: Would present with:

  • Ipsilateral facial weakness (CN VII)
  • Ipsilateral facial numbness (CN V)
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature
  • No Horner's syndrome

 

Option C. Medial Pons: Would present with:

  • Ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy (CN VI)
  • Contralateral hemiparesis
  • Contralateral loss of touch and proprioception

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recognizing the constellation of symptoms in lateral medullary syndrome is crucial for accurate localization and appropriate management. The presence of crossed sensory deficits (ipsilateral face, contralateral body) along with ipsilateral Horner's syndrome and cerebellar signs are pathognomonic.

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The gluteal tuberosity is indicated by the marked area in the photograph. The gluteus maximus, which is implanted here, produces lateral rotation and extension of the hip joint. Extension involves increasing the angle between the femur and the pelvis, essentially the opposite of flexion. Lateral rotation, refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.

 

Three-quarters of the gluteus maximus attach to the iliotibial tract, while one-fourth attach to the gluteal tuberosity (marked in image). The inferior gluteal nerve supplies it. At the hip joint, it serves as the primary extensor of the lower limb. Abduction and lateral rotation are additional effects.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Flexion and medial rotation:

 

  • Flexion is the movement of bending the joint, resulting in a decrease of the angle between the femur and the pelvis. Medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards, toward the midline.
  • The gluteus maximus is not primarily responsible for these actions. Instead, other muscles, such as the iliopsoas and anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, play roles in hip flexion and medial rotation.

 

Option B. Adduction and lateral rotation:

 

  • Adduction involves drawing the limb toward the midline of the body, while lateral rotation refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.
  • While the gluteus maximus does have fibers that can contribute to lateral rotation, it's not a primary adductor of the hip. Instead, the hip adductors (like adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus) primarily mediate adduction

 

Option C. Abduction and medial rotation:

 

  • Abduction involves moving the limb away from the midline, and as mentioned above, medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards.
  • The gluteus maximus is not a primary abductor or medial rotator of the hip. The gluteus medius and minimus are the primary muscles responsible for hip abduction, and various other muscles, including anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, contribute to medial rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus is a primary extensor and lateral rotator of the hip joint. When you stand up from a seated position, climb stairs, or rise from a squat, the gluteus maximus is heavily involved in extending the hip.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastriumis double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrosplenic Ligament: It is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It's a peritoneal fold that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels run within this ligament.

 

Option B. Lienorenal Ligament: It is also derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney. As with the gastrosplenic ligament, it's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum.

 

Option D. Gastrophrenic Ligament: it is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It is the portion of the greater omentum (which also has its origins in the dorsal mesogastrium) that attaches the stomach to the diaphragm. It's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation:

 

Presynaptic secretory vesicles are indicated by the asterisk in the electron micrograph. The structure with the arrowhead represents postsynaptic density.

 

Neurons produce secretory vesicles, which are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.

 

Synapse - electron microscopy

 

 

On electron microscopy:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria- On an electron microscope, mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies 0.5-2.0 micron long, with an outer and inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B.  Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory vesicles are essential for neurotransmission at synapses, and play the critical role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the following histological image: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glomerulus

 

The above histology image shows the glomerulus of a nephron.

 

Glomerulus is a tuft of capillaries located within Bowman's capsule in the renal cortex of the kidney. Here are the key histological features of the glomerulus:

 

  • Capillary Endothelium: The innermost layer of the glomerulus consists of fenestrated endothelial cells. These fenestrations or pores allow plasma (minus the larger proteins) to move from the blood into Bowman's space.
  • Basement Membrane: Surrounding the endothelial cells is the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It is a specialized extracellular matrix made up of type IV collagen, laminin, proteoglycans, and other glycoproteins. The GBM serves as a filter, preventing the passage of large proteins and cells but allowing smaller molecules to pass through.
  • Podocytes: These specialized epithelial cells cover the outer surface of the glomerular capillaries. They have foot processes called "pedicels" which interdigitate with one another, leaving filtration slits between them. The slit diaphragm, formed by intercellular junctions between adjacent pedicels, provides an additional barrier to the filtration of plasma proteins.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillaries of the glomerulus, mesangial cells have phagocytic activity and help in the structural support of the capillaries. They can also contract, thus regulating the blood flow through the glomerulus. Additionally, mesangial cells produce extracellular matrix components.
  • Juxtaglomerular Cells: These specialized smooth muscle cells are found in the afferent arteriole at the point of entry into the glomerulus. They secrete renin, a crucial enzyme in the renin-angiotensin system which regulates blood pressure.
  • Macula Densa: Although not a part of the glomerulus, the macula densa is closely related. It is a group of tall, closely packed cells in the distal convoluted tubule that detect changes in the sodium chloride levels in the filtrate and communicate with the juxtaglomerular cells to regulate renin secretion.
  • Bowman's Capsule: This is a double-layered capsule that surrounds the glomerulus. The inner layer, or visceral layer, is composed of podocytes. The outer layer, or parietal layer, is made up of a simple squamous epithelium. Between these two layers is the Bowman's space, into which the filtrate from the blood accumulates before moving into the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leydig Cells, also known as interstitial cells of Leydig, are present in the interstitial connective between seminiferous tubules.

 

The testis contains numerous seminiferous tubules separated by connective tissue in between.

 

Seminiferous tubules are lined by several spermatogonia cells, which produce spermatozoa, and Sertoli (sustentacular) cells, which have a supportive function.The connective tissue in between the tubules is made up of Leydig cells, collagen fibers, fibroblasts, macrophages, mast cells, blood vessels, and lymphatics. Leydig cells are large, round, or polyhedral cells with eccentric nuclei. They are lightly stained and often have a foamy appearance. They secrete testosterone upon stimulation by luteinizing hormone from the anterior pituitary.

 

The image below shows seminiferous tubules and Leydig cells

 

 

Option B: Islets of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

 

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. The islet cells are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

﻿﻿ The islet of Langerhans is mainly composed of three types of cells:

 

  • α or A cells - located peripherally and secrete glucagon
  • β or B cells - located centrally and produce insulin
  • δ or D cells - scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin

 

The image given below shows the islets of Langerhans

 

 

Option C: The thymic medulla contains fewer lymphocytes than the cortex, and the epithelial cells (E) located here have different morphology and function. The most characteristic feature of the medulla in humans is the presence of thymic (Hassall) corpuscles (H). These are of variable size and contain aggregates of thymic epithelial cells releasing many cytokines important within the medullary microenvironment, especially for dendritic cell activity and for the differentiation of regulatory T cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glomerulus consists of a network of capillaries encased within Bowman's capsule, playing a key role in blood filtration.

questions.text: Neurovascular bundle is absent in which compartment of the leg? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior superficial compartment

 

There is no neurovascular bundle in the leg's posterior superficial compartment.

 

The transverse intermuscular septum divides the posterior compartment of the leg into deep and superficial compartments.

 

The gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soles muscles are found in the posterior superficial compartment.

    

 

Neurovascular components in various compartments of leg are as follows:

 

  • Anterior compartment: Anterior tibial artery and Deep fibular/peroneal nerve
  • Posterior deep compartment: Tibial nerve and posterior tibial vessels in the deep plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment primarily contains the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis (fibularis longus and fibularis brevis in newer nomenclature).
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve. The blood supply comes from branches of the anterior tibial and fibular (peroneal) arteries.

 

Option C. Posterior Deep Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment contains the popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and tibialis posterior.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. The blood supply primarily comes from the posterior tibial artery.

 

Option D. Anterior Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment houses the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and fibularis (peroneus) tertius.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve. The anterior tibial artery supplies blood to this compartment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Superficial Compartment has the gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris muscles. These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. However, this compartment does not have a specific named artery or vein running through it, as the main vessels (the posterior tibial and fibular arteries and their accompanying veins) are located deep in the leg, closer to the bones. Instead, the vascular supply to these muscles comes from branching vessels that penetrate the compartment.

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

 

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

 

The ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal is called the "Lisfranc ligament".

 

The Lisfranc ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone in the foot. It is named after Jacques Lisfranc, a French surgeon who described amputations through this region during the Napoleonic Wars. The Lisfranc joint complex also includes the articulation between the other cuneiform bones and the metatarsals, as well as the tarsometatarsal ligaments and interosseous ligaments. The Lisfranc ligament is important for maintaining stability of the midfoot and for transferring forces from the hindfoot to the forefoot during walking and running. Injuries to the Lisfranc joint can result in significant disability and may require surgery to repair or stabilize the joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chopart Ligament: Chopart's ligament is not a well-known ligament in the foot. The term "Chopart joint" typically refers to the midtarsal joint, which includes the articulation between the talus and navicular (talocalcaneonavicular joint) and the calcaneus and cuboid (calcaneocuboid joint). Ligaments associated with these joints help maintain their stability.

 

Option B. Spring Ligament: The spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone. It is a vital structure for supporting the arch of the foot and preventing its collapse.

 

Option D. Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial side of the ankle joint. It is a complex ligament that attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and connects to various tarsal bones, such as the talus, calcaneus, and navicular. The deltoid ligament plays a significant role in stabilizing the ankle joint and preventing excessive eversion (outward rolling) of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lisfranc ligament is specifically associated with the connection between the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a strong ligament that helps stabilize the midfoot and prevents dislocation of the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints. Injury to this ligament is commonly referred to as a Lisfranc injury, which can result from traumatic events like falls or sports injuries.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve

 

The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:

 

  1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
  2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
  3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibers to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
  4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
  5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

 

Other marked structures:

 

  • 1- Optic nerve
  • 2- Abducent nerve
  • 4- Vestibulo cochlear nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve (II): The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is purely sensory in function. It begins at the retina, passes through the optic canal of the sphenoid bone, and joins the optic nerve of the opposite side at the optic chiasm. At this junction, fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross over.  Damage to the optic nerve can result in vision loss. Glaucoma, a condition with increased intraocular pressure, can damage the optic nerve and lead to blindness.

 

Option B. Abducent Nerve (VI): This nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally). It originates in the pons of the brainstem and travels through the superior orbital fissure to reach the orbit. Damage to this nerve can result in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a condition called lateral rectus palsy. This can manifest as double vision (diplopia) when looking to the side.

 

Option D. Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII): It has two parts: the cochlear nerve (for hearing) and the vestibular nerve (for balance). It originates in the inner ear and enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. Damage can lead to issues like sensorineural hearing loss or balance disorders like vertigo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trigeminal Nerve (V) is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions. Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing). 

 

It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).

 

The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets. 

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.

 

The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:

 

  • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to the marked bony structure? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iliopsoas

 

Explanation:

 

The radiograph shows a lateral view of the pelvis and proximal femur. The marked bony structure is the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major muscles, attaches to the lesser trochanter.

 

The iliopsoas crosses the hip joint anteriorly, causing flexion. The iliacus originates from the iliac fossa, while the psoas major originates from the lumbar vertebrae. These two muscles fuse together and insert near the lesser trochanter of the femur, forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gluteus maximus : The gluteus maximus muscle inserts on the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option C. Gluteus medius : The gluteus medius muscle inserts on the greater trochanter of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option D. Sartorius : The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle but does not attach directly to the lesser trochanter. It inserts on the medial surface of the proximal tibia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major, inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. It is an important hip flexor muscle.

 

Femoral Triangle:

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

 

Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

 

An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal Oblique:  The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B. External Oblique: The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C. Parietal Peritoneum: The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.

 

  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia Transversalis: The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum. It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.

 

Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.
